evidence_items.citation_apa: Fombonne, E., & Cook, E. (2003). MMR and autistic enterocolitis: Consistent epidemiological failure to find an association. Molecular Psychiatry, 8(2), 133–134.

evidence_items.description: The Lancet retracted the 1998 Wakefield et al. paper linking MMR vaccination to autism in February 2010 after an investigation found data fabrication, unethical procedures, and undeclared conflicts of interest, discrediting the original hypothesis of a vaccine-induced autism mechanism.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Boseley, S. (2010, February 2). Lancet retracts 'utterly false' MMR paper. The Guardian. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/feb/02/lancet-retracts-mmr-paper

evidence_items.description: A 1998 case series in The Lancet described 12 children with ileal-lymphoid-nodular hyperplasia, non-specific colitis, and pervasive developmental disorder, suggesting a temporal association between measles-containing vaccines and onset of autism symptoms.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Wakefield MR, et al. (1998). Ileal-lymphoid-nodular hyperplasia, non-specific colitis, and pervasive developmental disorder in children. Lancet, 351(9103), 637–641. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(97)11096-0

evidence_items.description: A population-based cohort study of 537,303 Danish children found no increased risk of autism among children who received the MMR vaccine compared to unvaccinated children.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Madsen KM, et al. (2002). A population-based study of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccination and autism. New England Journal of Medicine, 347(19), 1477–1482. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJM200211143471901

evidence_items.description: A UK case-control study of 1,397 children found no epidemiologic evidence linking MMR vaccination to autism.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Taylor B, et al. (1999). Autism and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine: No epidemiologic evidence for a causal association. BMJ, 321(7269), 1029–1033. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.321.7269.1029

evidence_items.description: A nationwide Danish cohort of 657,461 children born 1999–2010 showed no increased hazard of autism following MMR vaccination, including in subgroups at higher genetic risk.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Hviid A, Hansen JV, Frisch M, Melbye M. (2019). Measles, mumps, rubella vaccination and autism: A nationwide cohort study. Annals of Internal Medicine, 170(8), 513–520. https://doi.org/10.7326/M18-2101

evidence_items.description: In a cohort of children, total antigens from vaccines received up to age 2 and maximum antigens in a single visit were not associated with neuropsychological outcomes or ASD diagnosis at age 7–10 years.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Iqbal S, Barile JP, Thompson WW, DeStefano F. (2013). Number of antigens in early childhood vaccines and neuropsychological outcomes at age 7–10 years. Pharmacoepidemiology and Drug Safety, 22(12), 1263–1270. https://doi.org/10.1002/pds.3482

evidence_items.description: The 2004 Institute of Medicine review concluded that epidemiological evidence favors rejection of a causal relationship between thimerosal-containing vaccines or MMR vaccination and autism, finding biological mechanisms theoretical only.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2004). Immunization Safety Review: Vaccines and Autism. National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/10997

evidence_items.description: A 2025 preprint critique of Hviid et al.’s 2019 cohort study argued that healthy-user bias among unvaccinated children could mask a true association between MMR vaccination and autism.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Preprints.org. (2025). Hviid et al. 2019 Vaccine-Autism Study: Much Ado About Nothing? v2. https://doi.org/10.20944/preprints202501.0796.v2

evidence_items.description: A November 2025 CDC webpage update stated that studies have not definitively ruled out infant vaccines as a contributor to autism, reversing prior consensus that vaccines do not cause autism.
evidence_items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
evidence_items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2025, November 19). Autism and Vaccines. U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. https://beta.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/about/autism.html

evidence_items.description: A cohort of 196,929 children showed no significant association between maternal influenza vaccination during any trimester and ASD risk in offspring after adjustment for multiple comparisons.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Zerbo O, et al. (2017). Association between influenza infection and vaccination during pregnancy and risk of autism spectrum disorder. JAMA Pediatrics, 171(1), e163609. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamapediatrics.2016.3609

evidence_items.description: An Institute of Medicine committee reviewed over 1,000 articles and found no or insufficient evidence to support a causal relationship between MMR vaccination and autism, concluding “the MMR vaccine does not cause autism.”
evidence_items.citation_apa: Clark, C. (2011, August 26). MMR Vaccine Does Not Cause Autism, Says IOM. HealthLeaders Media.

evidence_items.description: Ecological analysis of Danish registers (1971–2000) showed autism incidence continued to rise after the removal of thimerosal from vaccines in 1992, with no correlation between thimerosal exposure levels (0–400 µg Hg) and autism risk (p=0.40).
evidence_items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., & Plesner, A.-M. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: Negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3 Pt 1), 604–606. doi:10.1542/peds.112.3.Part1.604

evidence_items.description: In a US retrospective cohort of 95,727 children with older siblings, MMR vaccination was not associated with increased ASD risk at age 2 (RR 0.76; 95% CI 0.49–1.18) or age 5 (RR 0.56; 95% CI 0.31–1.01) among high-risk children, indicating no subgroup vulnerability.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Jain, A., Marshall, J., Buikema, A., Bancroft, T., Kelly, J. P., & Newschaffer, C. J. (2015). Autism occurrence by MMR vaccine status among US children with older siblings with and without autism. JAMA, 313(15), 1534–1540. doi:10.1001/jama.2015.3077

evidence_items.description: Case-control study of 256 ASD and 752 control children found no association between cumulative or maximum daily antigen exposure from vaccines in the first two years and ASD risk, despite antigen loads decreasing from thousands to 315 over decades.
evidence_items.citation_apa: DeStefano, F., Price, C. S., & Weintraub, E. (2013). Risk of autism is not increased by 'too many vaccines too soon,' study shows. The Journal of Pediatrics, 163(1), 79–85. doi:10.1016/j.jpeds.2013.01.029

evidence_items.description: In a Danish cohort of 537,303 children, MMR-vaccinated children (n=440,655) had an adjusted relative risk (RR) of autism of 0.92 (95% CI, 0.68–1.24) and ASD of 0.83 (95% CI, 0.65–1.07), indicating no increased risk of autism following MMR vaccination.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Hviid, A., Vestergaard, M., Schendel, D., Wohlfahrt, J., Thorsen, P., Olsen, J., & Melbye, M. (2002). A population-based study of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccination and autism. New England Journal of Medicine, 347(19), 1477-1482. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa021134

evidence_items.description: After discontinuation of thimerosal-containing vaccines in Denmark in 1992, the incidence of autism continued to rise from 1991 to 2000 among children aged 2–10 years, with no decline in autism rates following thimerosal removal.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., Plesner, A. M., Andersen, P. H., & Mortensen, P. B. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: Negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3 Pt 1), 604-606. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.112.3.604

evidence_items.description: An updated Cochrane review of MMR, MMRV, and MMR+V vaccines found no evidence of increased autism risk and confirmed vaccine effectiveness, with moderate-to-high certainty across studies up to May 2019.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Di Pietrantonj, C., Rivetti, A., Marchione, P., Debalini, M. G., & Demicheli, V. (2019). Vaccines for measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 2019(4), CD004407. https://doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub2

evidence_items.description: In a case-control study of 256 ASD cases and 752 controls, increasing cumulative exposure to vaccine antigens up to age 2 years showed no association with ASD risk (aOR per 25-unit antigen increase ranged from 0.999 to 1.001).
evidence_items.citation_apa: DeStefano, F., Price, C. S., & Weintraub, E. S. (2013). Increasing exposure to antibody-stimulating proteins and polysaccharides in vaccines is not associated with risk of autism. Journal of Pediatrics, 163(2), 561-567. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpeds.2013.02.001

evidence_items.description: CDC states that extensive studies have found no link between receiving vaccines and developing ASD, and that no vaccine ingredients have been associated with increased autism risk.
evidence_items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
evidence_items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2024, December 30). Autism and vaccines. CDC. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/about/autism.html

evidence_items.description: The Institute of Medicine’s 2011 report reviewed over 1,000 studies of eight vaccines and concluded there is no causal relationship between vaccination and autism, stating the evidence favors rejection of any causal link.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2011). Adverse Effects of Vaccines: Evidence and Causality. Washington, DC: National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/13164

evidence_items.description: The Editors of The Lancet formally retracted the 1998 Wakefield et al. paper in February 2010 after the UK General Medical Council found data falsification and unethical procedures, invalidating the initial suggestion of an MMR-autism link.
evidence_items.citation_apa: The Editors of The Lancet. (2010). Retraction—Ileal-lymphoid-nodular hyperplasia, non‐specific colitis, and pervasive developmental disorder in children. The Lancet. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(10)60175-7

evidence_items.description: The WHO Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety’s December 2025 review of 31 primary studies (2010–2025) and meta-analyses reaffirmed that vaccines, including those with thiomersal or aluminum adjuvants, do not cause ASD.
evidence_items.citation_apa: World Health Organization. (2025, December 11). WHO expert group’s new analysis reaffirms there is no link between vaccines and autism. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.who.int/news/item/11-12-2025-who-expert-group-s-new-analysis-reaffirms-there-is-no-link-between-vaccines-and-autism

evidence_items.description: A systematic review of 67 studies on routine pediatric vaccines in the United States found high-strength evidence that the MMR vaccine is not associated with autism, and moderate evidence of rare adverse events (e.g., intussusception with rotavirus vaccine), underscoring the overall safety of the immunization schedule.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Maglione, M. A., Das, L., Raaen, L., Smith, A., Chari, R., Newberry, S., Shanman, R., Perry, T., Goetz, M. B., & Gidengil, C. (2014). Safety of vaccines used for routine immunization of US children: A systematic review. Pediatrics, 134(2), 325–337. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.2014-1079

evidence_items.description: An analysis of unethical research practices and methodological flaws in studies promoting a vaccine–autism link, documenting fraudulent science associated with Andrew Wakefield and subsequent proponents, and highlighting the public health risks of such misinformation.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Flaherty, D. K. (2011). The vaccine–autism connection: A public health crisis caused by unethical medical practices and fraudulent science. Annals of Pharmacotherapy, 45(10), 1302–1304. https://doi.org/10.1345/aph.1P470

evidence_items.description: Geier & Geier (2003) analyzed the VAERS database and Department of Education data, finding dose-response curves indicating that increased cumulative mercury exposure from thimerosal-containing childhood vaccines correlated with higher rates of autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Geier, D. A., & Geier, M. R. (2003). An assessment of the impact of thimerosal on childhood neurodevelopmental disorders. Pediatric Rehabilitation, 6(2), 97–102. https://doi.org/10.1080/1363849031000139315

evidence_items.description: Geier & Geier (2003) reported in Experimental Biology and Medicine that analysis of VAERS data showed a relative risk of 6.0 for autism and 6.1 for mental retardation following thimerosal-containing DTaP vaccines compared to thimerosal-free formulations.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Geier, M. R., & Geier, D. A. (2003). Neurodevelopmental disorders after thimerosal-containing vaccines: a brief communication. Experimental Biology and Medicine, 228(6), 660–664. https://doi.org/10.1177/153537020322800603

evidence_items.description: Madsen et al. (2003) analyzed Danish population-based data and observed that autism prevalence continued to rise following the removal of thimerosal from childhood vaccines in 1992, providing negative ecological evidence for a thimerosal-autism link.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., & Plesner, A. M. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3), 604–606. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.112.3.604

evidence_items.description: The Institute of Medicine Immunization Safety Review Committee (2004) concluded that the body of epidemiological evidence favors rejection of a causal relationship between both the MMR vaccine and thimerosal-containing vaccines and autism.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2004). Immunization Safety Review: Vaccines and Autism. National Academies Press. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK25344/

evidence_items.description: A nationwide Danish cohort study of 657,461 children born between 1999 and 2010 found that receipt of the MMR vaccine was not associated with an increased risk for autism (hazard ratio for vaccinated vs. unvaccinated children not significantly different from 1).
evidence_items.citation_apa: Hviid, A., Hansen, J. V., Frisch, M., & Melbye, M. (2019). Measles, mumps, rubella vaccination and autism: A nationwide cohort study. Annals of Internal Medicine, 170(8), 513–520. doi:10.7326/M18-2101

evidence_items.description: Ecological analysis of Danish children aged 2–10 diagnosed with autism from 1971 to 2000 showed no decline in autism incidence following removal of thimerosal from vaccines in 1992; autism rates continued to rise, refuting any correlation with thimerosal exposure.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., Plesner, A. M., Andersen, P. H., & Mortensen, P. B. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: Negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3 Pt 1), 604–606. doi:10.1542/peds.112.3.604

evidence_items.description: A Cochrane systematic review of MMR, MMRV, and MMR+V vaccines (up to May 2019) in over 13 million children found no evidence of increased autism risk among vaccinated vs. unvaccinated groups, while affirming vaccine effectiveness.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Di Pietrantonj, C., Rivetti, A., Marchione, P., Debalini, M. G., & Demicheli, V. (2012). Vaccines for measles, mumps, rubella and varicella in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 2, CD004407. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3

evidence_items.description: Case-control study of 256 ASD cases and 752 matched controls in three U.S. managed care organizations found no association between prenatal or infant thimerosal (ethylmercury) exposure and risk of ASD, autistic disorder, or ASD with regression.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Price, C. S., Thompson, W. W., Goodson, B., Weintraub, E. S., Croen, L. A., Hinrichsen, V. L., Marcy, M., Robertson, A., Eriksen, E., Lewis, E., Bernal, P., Shay, D., Davis, R. L., & DeStefano, F. (2010). Prenatal and infant exposure to thimerosal from vaccines and immunoglobulins and risk of autism. Pediatrics, 126(4), 656–664. doi:10.1542/peds.2010-0309

evidence_items.description: In a reanalysis of CDC data involving African American male children, vaccination with the first MMR dose before 24 months of age was associated with a 1.73-fold increased risk of autism diagnosis, and vaccination before 36 months was associated with a 3.36-fold increased risk, compared to later vaccination timing.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Hooker, B. S. (2014). Measles-mumps-rubella vaccination timing and autism among young African American boys: A reanalysis of CDC data. Translational Neurodegeneration, 3, 16. https://doi.org/10.1186/2047-9158-3-16

evidence_items.description: A cross-national preprint analysis of 12 high-income countries found a positive association between early-life vaccine scheduling intensity (number of doses administered to infants under one year) and standardized autism incidence rates, with higher-dose countries averaging 20 doses in the first year showing elevated autism prevalence compared to countries with fewer doses.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Coccia, M. (2025). Infant vaccine scheduling intensity and autism incidence: A preliminary cross-national analysis to guide public health policy [Preprint]. Preprints.org. https://www.preprints.org/manuscript/202511.0675

evidence_items.description: Brookings Institution experts argue that there is no scientific evidence supporting alternative ‘‘spaced-out’’ vaccine schedules for safety, noting that major reviews, including by the IOM, found no concerns with the current timing and that spacing delays increase risks for preventable diseases.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Brookings Institution. (2026). Vaccines and nervous parents: Why spacing out the vaccine schedule is not the answer. Brookings. https://www.brookings.edu/articles/vaccines-and-nervous-parents-why-spacing-out-the-vaccine-schedule-is-not-the-answer/

evidence_items.description: The Institute of Medicine’s 2013 comprehensive review of the U.S. childhood immunization schedule found no evidence that the timing, number, or order of vaccines is linked to autism or other developmental disorders, though it called for research on outcomes in children with delayed schedules.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2013). The Childhood Immunization Schedule and Safety: Stakeholder Concerns, Scientific Evidence, and Future Studies. National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/13563

evidence_items.description: In October 2025, the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices announced a multi-year review of the U.S. childhood vaccine schedule specifically to study timing and sequence of vaccinations, including alternative schedules used abroad and potential subgroup vulnerabilities.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Politico. (2025, October 9). CDC panel announces plans to assess childhood vaccine schedule. Politico. https://www.politico.com/news/2025/10/09/cdc-panel-to-assess-childhood-vaccine-schedule-00600304

evidence_items.description: A Medical Daily report summarizing a review of nearly 1,000 children concluded there is no evidence linking the timing or scheduling of childhood vaccines to the development of autism spectrum disorder.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Medical Daily. (2025). Study confirms no link between childhood vaccine schedule and autism. Medical Daily. https://www.medicaldaily.com/study-confirms-no-link-between-childhood-vaccine-schedule-and-autism-244822

evidence_clusters.description: Large cohort/case-control studies and meta-analyses examining MMR, thimerosal/ethylmercury, antigen load, prenatal influenza vaccination, and temporal/timing variables; overwhelmingly report no association with ASD.

H0.justification: Catch-all/OTHER does not specifically predict that repeated large studies will be null or positive; treat as independent of this evidence cluster → set to base rate exactly (LR=1).

H1.justification: If vaccines directly cause autism at a detectable population level, repeated large studies/meta-analyses would more often find an association; thus observing repeated nulls is much less likely than base rate.

H2.justification: If no causal link exists, repeated large studies should mostly report null associations; thus this null-heavy cluster is much more likely than base rate.

H3.justification: If only a rare vulnerable subgroup exists, most population-wide studies still tend to be null; so the cluster is somewhat more likely than base rate, though not as strongly as under H2.

H4.justification: An indirect/rare immune-interaction pathway would generally yield weak/rare effects, so many null epidemiologic findings remain somewhat expected; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule/timing effects exist only in limited circumstances, many broad studies would still be null; slightly above base rate (but less than H2), acknowledging some items in this cluster directly test timing/antigen-load.

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive about whether mainstream epidemiology yields null vs positive findings; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If one suspects residual confounding/healthy-user bias and publication/selection effects, null epidemiology is less surprising even if H1 were true; still somewhat below base rate because many independent datasets would not all wash out a real effect.

H2.justification: Null findings remain more expected under no-causation, but methodological skepticism reduces how strongly this cluster is predicted vs base rate.

H3.justification: Rare subgroup effects still allow many null results; modestly above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare effects are compatible with many nulls; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule effects could be hard to detect in standard observational designs; modestly above base rate but close to it under methodological skepticism.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict the direction of epidemiologic findings; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under a strongly vaccine-skeptical stance (systematic bias/suppression assumed), many null studies are expected even if a true effect exists; thus slightly above base rate rather than below.

H2.justification: Even under skepticism, null findings are still somewhat expected if there is no causal link; only slightly above base rate because the paradigm treats these results as less diagnostic.

H3.justification: Rare subgroup effects plus assumed detection limitations make null-heavy literature plausible; modestly above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare pathways can evade detection; modestly above base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule effects are real but obscured, null epidemiology is not very surprising; slightly above base rate.

evidence_clusters.description: Consensus statements and major reviews (IOM/NASEM, CDC, AAP, WHO, Brookings expert commentary, and similar) concluding no link between vaccines (including MMR, thimerosal/aluminum) and autism, and/or no schedule-timing link.

H0.justification: OTHER does not specifically predict whether institutions converge on 'no link' vs 'link'; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If vaccines truly cause autism broadly, strong cross-institutional consensus repeatedly rejecting a link is less likely than base rate (would expect more equivocation or positive findings).

H2.justification: If no causal link exists, major institutions reviewing large bodies of evidence are very likely to converge on 'no link'; far above base rate.

H3.justification: A rare subgroup effect could still yield broad institutional 'no population-level link' conclusions, but strong categorical messaging ('no link') is somewhat less expected than under H2; slightly below base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare immune-interaction effects would plausibly lead to more hedged institutional language; thus repeated strong 'no link' consensus is somewhat less likely than base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule timing/sequence truly mattered, large reviews specifically of schedules would be less likely to conclude 'no evidence'; thus below base rate.

H0.justification: Under skepticism about institutional incentives, consensus statements become less tied to underlying causal truth; OTHER still makes no specific prediction → set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If institutions are biased/motivated, 'no link' consensus could still occur even if H1 were true; thus only slightly below base rate.

H2.justification: Even with institutional skepticism, a true no-link world still modestly increases the chance institutions say 'no link'; slightly above base rate (reduced diagnosticity).

H3.justification: If institutions are not strongly truth-tracking, rare-subgroup hypotheses do not strongly change expected consensus outputs; approximately at base rate (treated as near-non-diagnostic here).

H4.justification: Same rationale as H3 under this paradigm: institutional conclusions expected to be relatively insensitive to nuanced indirect pathways → set near base rate.

H5.justification: If the schedule question is politically charged, institutions might still state reassurance regardless; treat as near base rate (low diagnosticity).

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive regarding institutional messaging; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under a strong vaccine-skeptic paradigm (institutional capture/suppression assumed), institutional 'no link' statements are expected even if vaccines cause autism; thus above base rate.

H2.justification: If there is truly no link, institutions may also say 'no link'; but under this paradigm such statements are not strongly truth-indicative, so only slightly below/near base rate (set slightly below to reflect expectation of institutional reassurance regardless).

H3.justification: If only a subgroup is affected, this paradigm still expects broad institutional denial; above base rate.

H4.justification: Same as H3 under K2: denial/consensus messaging expected even with nuanced indirect harm; above base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule effects exist, K2 expects institutions to continue reassuring the public; above base rate.

evidence_clusters.cluster_name: Wakefield episode: initial signal, then retraction/fraud analysis
evidence_clusters.description: The original small 1998 case series suggesting a temporal association, followed by formal retractions and analyses documenting methodological flaws/fraud and unethical practices.

H0.justification: OTHER does not specifically predict 'a flawed early study appears and is later retracted'; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If vaccines truly cause autism, one expects better-quality replicable signals rather than a landmark claim collapsing into fraud/retraction; thus this cluster is less likely than base rate.

H2.justification: If no causal link exists, early spurious associations plus subsequent correction/retraction is relatively likely; above base rate.

H3.justification: A rare-subgroup truth could still generate small early signals, but full fraud/retraction is less expected than under H2; modestly above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare pathway could allow early suggestive reports, but wholesale invalidation remains more consistent with 'no link'; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule/timing effects could produce apparent temporal patterns, but this particular episode being fraudulent/retracted is not strongly predicted; slightly above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict this historical sequence; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If one allows for social/political contestation, retractions can occur even when some underlying risk exists; still below base rate because fraud findings weaken the expectation under H1.

H2.justification: Spurious early claims corrected later are expected under H2, but K1 reduces trust in the 'retraction implies false' inference; moderately above base rate.

H3.justification: Rare subgroup effects plus noisy early research could still end in retraction; slightly above base rate.

H4.justification: Similar to H3 under K1; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Timing-only theories are not strongly illuminated by this episode; near base rate but slightly above.

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive about this episode; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under a suppression/censorship paradigm, a prominent pro-link paper later retracted is expected if H1 is true; above base rate.

H2.justification: If no link exists, K2 considers retraction less diagnostic (could be politicized); thus only slightly below base rate.

H3.justification: If a subgroup effect exists, K2 still expects pushback/retraction dynamics; above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect pathways plus perceived suppression makes this episode somewhat expected; above base rate.

H5.justification: Timing/schedule theories can align with temporal narratives that later face institutional rejection; above base rate.

evidence_clusters.description: Animal/translational evidence that maternal immune activation can produce autism-like phenotypes, suggesting immune-mediated pathways could influence neurodevelopment (not vaccine-specific per se).

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict whether immune-activation animal models exist; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Direct vaccine-causation hypotheses often invoke immune activation/neuroinflammation mechanisms, so seeing such mechanistic models is somewhat more likely than base rate.

H2.justification: No-link between vaccines and autism is compatible with immune activation affecting neurodevelopment via infections/other exposures; not a specific vaccine prediction → set to base rate.

H3.justification: Subgroup vulnerability hypotheses predict that immune-related susceptibilities could matter; thus mechanistic immune-activation models are somewhat more likely than base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect pathway via immune activation explicitly predicts mechanistic support for immune-mediated neurodevelopmental disruption; well above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule-overload is not specifically about maternal immune activation in pregnancy; this evidence is largely orthogonal → set to base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER makes no specific prediction; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Mechanistic plausibility evidence is treated as more suggestive under K1; somewhat above base rate.

H2.justification: Still compatible and not specifically predicted by H2; set to base rate.

H3.justification: Immune-vulnerability framing fits subgroup susceptibility; above base rate.

H4.justification: Immune-activation mechanism is central to H4; above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule/timing hypotheses weakly connect via immune load ideas; slightly above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER is non-predictive; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under K2, immune activation animal models are taken as strong support for vaccine causation narratives; above base rate.

H2.justification: K2 treats immune-activation evidence as conflicting with 'no vaccine contribution'; thus below base rate.

H3.justification: K2 expects immune susceptibility to matter for a subgroup; above base rate.

H4.justification: Immune-activation pathway is strongly aligned; well above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule-overload claims often invoke immune mechanisms; somewhat above base rate.

evidence_clusters.cluster_name: Contrarian/contested evidence & ongoing reviews (VAERS/ecological signals, preprints, subgroup/timing claims, policy noise)
evidence_clusters.description: Weaker/contested pro-link claims (VAERS-based analyses, subgroup/timing reanalyses), critiques alleging bias in null studies, cross-national schedule correlations, and signals of renewed review/uncertainty; includes some mixed media summaries around schedule.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict the appearance of a mixed set of contrarian studies/claims and review announcements; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If vaccines cause autism, one expects at least some positive signals and persistent controversy; thus this cluster is more likely than base rate (even if individual items are low-quality).

H2.justification: If there is truly no causal link, some noise/false positives occur, but a concentration of pro-link claims plus policy 'reconsideration' is less likely than base rate.

H3.justification: Rare-subgroup effects predict occasional subgroup/timing signals and ongoing debate; above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect immune interactions could yield sporadic and hard-to-replicate signals; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Timing/schedule hypotheses predict schedule-intensity correlations and renewed schedule review; above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If true harm exists and mainstream methods miss it, K1 expects persistent dissent, bias critiques, and positive signals in alternative analyses; above base rate.

H2.justification: Even with no link, motivated reasoning and p-hacking can yield contrarian signals; still below base rate but less strongly than K0.

H3.justification: Subgroup vulnerability fits occasional subgroup findings and ongoing re-analysis; above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect pathways can be subtle and contested; modestly above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule/timing concerns predict continued debate, ecological correlations, and institutional reviews; above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict these specific contested signals; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under K2, contrarian signals, VAERS-based associations, subgroup timing effects, and policy reconsiderations are expected manifestations of a real causal relationship; well above base rate.

H2.justification: If no link exists, K2 views this cluster as comparatively unlikely; below base rate.

H3.justification: K2 expects subgroup signals and disputes if only some children are vulnerable; above base rate.

H4.justification: K2 expects immune-mediated controversies and sporadic signals; above base rate.

H5.justification: K2 expects schedule-intensity associations and renewed schedule scrutiny if timing matters; well above base rate.

scenario_config.proposition: Do vaccines cause autism in children?

paradigms.name: Scientific Consensus
paradigms.description: Mainstream scientific and medical consensus based on epidemiological evidence, meta-analyses, and mechanistic biology.
paradigms.epistemology: Empirical observation, RCTs, systematic reviews, falsification
paradigms.axiology: Public health, harm reduction, evidence-based medicine

paradigms.name: Vaccine Skeptic
paradigms.description: Perspective that questions vaccine safety claims, emphasizes anecdotal reports, and distrusts pharmaceutical/regulatory institutions.
paradigms.epistemology: Personal testimony, pattern recognition in adverse event reports
paradigms.axiology: Parental autonomy, precaution, distrust of authority

paradigms.name: Precautionary
paradigms.description: Accepts most vaccine science but emphasizes unknown long-term risks and subgroup vulnerabilities.

hypotheses.name: OTHER - Unforeseen explanation
hypotheses.description: Some unknown factor not captured by the other hypotheses explains the relationship (or lack thereof) between vaccines and autism.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Vaccines directly cause autism
hypotheses.description: Vaccines (or their components like thimerosal, aluminum adjuvants, or antigens) directly cause autism through biological mechanisms such as immune activation, neurotoxicity, or gut-brain axis disruption.

hypotheses.name: FALSE - No causal link exists
hypotheses.description: There is no causal relationship between vaccines and autism. The temporal correlation (vaccines given around age when autism symptoms appear) is coincidental. Large epidemiological studies consistently show no increased risk.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Rare subgroup vulnerability
hypotheses.description: While vaccines don't cause autism in the general population, a small subset of genetically or immunologically vulnerable children may experience adverse neurodevelopmental effects. This subgroup is too small to detect in population studies.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Indirect pathway via immune activation
hypotheses.description: Vaccines don't directly cause autism, but in rare cases, the immune response they trigger may interact with pre-existing conditions to affect neurodevelopment. The effect is real but indirect and context-dependent.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Timing/schedule effects only
hypotheses.description: Individual vaccines are safe, but the cumulative effect of the vaccination schedule (multiple vaccines in short timeframes) may overwhelm some children's immune systems, contributing to developmental issues in susceptible individuals.

items.description: In a retrospective cohort study of 537,303 children born in Denmark from January 1991 through December 1998, the relative risk of autistic disorder among children who received the MMR vaccine compared with unvaccinated children was 0.92 (95% CI, 0.68–1.24), and for other autistic-spectrum disorders was 0.83 (95% CI, 0.65–1.07). No association was observed between age at vaccination, time since vaccination, or date of vaccination and development of autistic disorder.
items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Hviid, A., Vestergaard, M., Schendel, D., Wohlfahrt, J., Thorsen, P., Olsen, J., & Melbye, M. (2002). A population-based study of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccination and autism. New England Journal of Medicine, 347(19), 1477–1482. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa021134

items.description: The Institute of Medicine’s 2004 consensus report reviewed published and unpublished epidemiological studies and potential biological mechanisms and concluded that the body of epidemiological evidence favors rejection of a causal relationship between MMR and thimerosal-containing vaccines and autism, finding only theoretical support for any biologic mechanism.
items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2004). Immunization Safety Review: Vaccines and Autism. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/10997

items.description: A CDC-led case-control study of 256 children with ASD and 752 controls across three managed care organizations found that prenatal and infant exposure to thimerosal from vaccines and immunoglobulins was not associated with any increase in risk for autism spectrum disorder or its subtypes.
items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
items.citation_apa: Price, C. S., Thompson, W. W., Goodson, B., Weintraub, E. S., Croen, L. A., Hinrichsen, V. L., Marcy, M., Robertson, A., Erisken, E., Lewis, E., Bernal, P., Shay, D., Davis, R. L., & DeStefano, F. (2010). Prenatal and infant exposure to thimerosal from vaccines and immunoglobulins and risk of autism. Pediatrics, 126(4), 656–664. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.2010-0309

items.description: A 2014 evidence-based meta-analysis of five cohort studies (1,256,407 children) and five case-control studies (9,920 children) reported no relationship between vaccination and autism (OR 0.99; 95% CI, 0.92–1.06), ASD (OR 0.91; 95% CI, 0.68–1.20), MMR (OR 0.84; 95% CI, 0.70–1.01), thimerosal (OR 1.00; 95% CI, 0.77–1.31), or mercury (OR 1.00; 95% CI, 0.93–1.07).
items.citation_apa: Taylor, L. E., Swerdfeger, A. L., & Eslick, G. D. (2014). Vaccines are not associated with autism: An evidence-based meta-analysis of case-control and cohort studies. Vaccine, 32(29), 3623–3629. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vaccine.2014.04.085

items.description: Animal and translational studies reviewed by Patterson (2011) demonstrate that maternal immune activation during pregnancy induces offspring with behavioral and neuropathological features resembling autism, implicating interleukin-6–mediated immune pathways in fetal brain development.
items.citation_apa: Patterson, P. H. (2011). Maternal infection and immune involvement in autism. Trends in Molecular Medicine, 17(7), 389–394. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molmed.2011.03.001

items.description: In a population-based case-control study in metropolitan Atlanta of 625 children with autism and 1,824 matched controls, no significant difference was found in age at first MMR vaccination: 70.5% of cases and 67.5% of controls were vaccinated between 12 and 17 months, with no association observed at other age cutoffs.
items.citation_apa: DeStefano, F., Bhasin, B. K., Thompson, W. W., Yeargin-Allsopp, M., & Boyle, C. (2004). Age at first Measles-Mumps-Rubella vaccination in children with autism and school-matched control subjects: A population-based study in metropolitan Atlanta. Pediatrics, 113(2), 259–266. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.113.2.259

items.description: On February 2, 2010, editors of The Lancet fully retracted the 1998 Wakefield et al. paper linking MMR vaccination to autism, stating that key elements of the study were incorrect and that the lead author had been dishonest and unethical.
items.citation_apa: Dyer, C. (2010). Lancet retracts Wakefield’s MMR paper. BMJ, 340, c696. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.c696

items.description: The CDC’s MMR vaccine safety page states that multiple carefully performed studies—including IOM (2004) reviews and ongoing surveillance—have found no link between MMR vaccination and autism, and that signs of ASD appearing around vaccine administration reflect coincidence in timing.
items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2025). MMR Vaccine Safety. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/vaccines/mmr.html

items.description: A 2012 Cochrane systematic review of 64 studies evaluating MMR (and MMRV) vaccines in children up to age 15 found no evidence of an increased risk of autism following vaccination.
items.citation_apa: Demicheli, V., Rivetti, A., Debalini, M. G., & Di Pietrantonj, C. (2012). Vaccines for measles, mumps and rubella in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, (2), CD004407. https://doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3

items.description: In a population-based cohort study of 467,450 Danish children born between January 1, 1990, and December 31, 1996, comparing those who received thimerosal-containing pertussis vaccines to those who received thimerosal-free formulations, the rate ratio (RR) for autism among exposed children was 0.85 (95% CI, 0.60–1.20), with no dose-response trend observed per 25 µg ethylmercury (RR 0.98; 95% CI, 0.90–1.06).
items.citation_apa: Hviid, A., Stellfeld, M., Wohlfahrt, J., & Melbye, M. (2003). Association between thimerosal-containing vaccine and autism. JAMA, 290(13), 1763–1766.

items.description: The Institute of Medicine's 2004 Immunization Safety Review concluded, after reviewing over 200 studies, that neither the MMR vaccine nor thimerosal-containing vaccines are associated with autism and that proposed biological mechanisms remain theoretical without empirical support.
items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2004). Immunization Safety Review: Vaccines and Autism. National Academies Press. doi:10.17226/10997

items.description: The American Academy of Pediatrics' fact-checked resource affirms that rigorous research spanning decades has found no credible link between vaccines and autism, noting the retraction of fraudulent studies and emphasizing ongoing review of vaccine safety data.
items.citation_apa: American Academy of Pediatrics. (2025). Fact Checked: Vaccines: Safe and Effective, No Link to Autism. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.aap.org/en/news-room/fact-checked/fact-checked-vaccines-safe-and-effect-no-link-to-autism/

items.description: The World Health Organization's Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety reaffirmed in 2025, after reviewing 31 studies from 2010–2025, that there is no causal link between childhood vaccines (including those with thiomersal or aluminum adjuvants) and autism spectrum disorder, deeming outlier studies methodologically flawed.
items.citation_apa: People.com. (2025). WHO Reaffirms That 'Childhood Vaccines Do Not Cause Autism' After Reviewing Latest Research. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://people.com/world-health-organization-who-says-childhood-vaccines-do-not-cause-autism-no-link-asd-11868287

items.description: A correspondence in Molecular Psychiatry reported consistent epidemiological failure to find any association between MMR vaccination and autistic enterocolitis in multiple studies, reinforcing the absence of a vaccine-related gastrointestinal trigger for autism.
items.citation_apa: Fombonne, E., & Cook, E. (2003). MMR and autistic enterocolitis: Consistent epidemiological failure to find an association. Molecular Psychiatry, 8(2), 133–134.

items.description: The Lancet retracted the 1998 Wakefield et al. paper linking MMR vaccination to autism in February 2010 after an investigation found data fabrication, unethical procedures, and undeclared conflicts of interest, discrediting the original hypothesis of a vaccine-induced autism mechanism.
items.citation_apa: Boseley, S. (2010, February 2). Lancet retracts 'utterly false' MMR paper. The Guardian. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/feb/02/lancet-retracts-mmr-paper

items.description: A 1998 case series in The Lancet described 12 children with ileal-lymphoid-nodular hyperplasia, non-specific colitis, and pervasive developmental disorder, suggesting a temporal association between measles-containing vaccines and onset of autism symptoms.
items.citation_apa: Wakefield MR, et al. (1998). Ileal-lymphoid-nodular hyperplasia, non-specific colitis, and pervasive developmental disorder in children. Lancet, 351(9103), 637–641. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(97)11096-0

items.description: A population-based cohort study of 537,303 Danish children found no increased risk of autism among children who received the MMR vaccine compared to unvaccinated children.
items.citation_apa: Madsen KM, et al. (2002). A population-based study of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccination and autism. New England Journal of Medicine, 347(19), 1477–1482. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJM200211143471901

items.description: A UK case-control study of 1,397 children found no epidemiologic evidence linking MMR vaccination to autism.
items.citation_apa: Taylor B, et al. (1999). Autism and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine: No epidemiologic evidence for a causal association. BMJ, 321(7269), 1029–1033. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.321.7269.1029

items.description: A nationwide Danish cohort of 657,461 children born 1999–2010 showed no increased hazard of autism following MMR vaccination, including in subgroups at higher genetic risk.
items.citation_apa: Hviid A, Hansen JV, Frisch M, Melbye M. (2019). Measles, mumps, rubella vaccination and autism: A nationwide cohort study. Annals of Internal Medicine, 170(8), 513–520. https://doi.org/10.7326/M18-2101

items.description: In a cohort of children, total antigens from vaccines received up to age 2 and maximum antigens in a single visit were not associated with neuropsychological outcomes or ASD diagnosis at age 7–10 years.
items.citation_apa: Iqbal S, Barile JP, Thompson WW, DeStefano F. (2013). Number of antigens in early childhood vaccines and neuropsychological outcomes at age 7–10 years. Pharmacoepidemiology and Drug Safety, 22(12), 1263–1270. https://doi.org/10.1002/pds.3482

items.description: The 2004 Institute of Medicine review concluded that epidemiological evidence favors rejection of a causal relationship between thimerosal-containing vaccines or MMR vaccination and autism, finding biological mechanisms theoretical only.
items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2004). Immunization Safety Review: Vaccines and Autism. National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/10997

items.description: A 2025 preprint critique of Hviid et al.’s 2019 cohort study argued that healthy-user bias among unvaccinated children could mask a true association between MMR vaccination and autism.
items.citation_apa: Preprints.org. (2025). Hviid et al. 2019 Vaccine-Autism Study: Much Ado About Nothing? v2. https://doi.org/10.20944/preprints202501.0796.v2

items.description: A November 2025 CDC webpage update stated that studies have not definitively ruled out infant vaccines as a contributor to autism, reversing prior consensus that vaccines do not cause autism.
items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2025, November 19). Autism and Vaccines. U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. https://beta.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/about/autism.html

items.description: A cohort of 196,929 children showed no significant association between maternal influenza vaccination during any trimester and ASD risk in offspring after adjustment for multiple comparisons.
items.citation_apa: Zerbo O, et al. (2017). Association between influenza infection and vaccination during pregnancy and risk of autism spectrum disorder. JAMA Pediatrics, 171(1), e163609. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamapediatrics.2016.3609

items.description: An Institute of Medicine committee reviewed over 1,000 articles and found no or insufficient evidence to support a causal relationship between MMR vaccination and autism, concluding “the MMR vaccine does not cause autism.”
items.citation_apa: Clark, C. (2011, August 26). MMR Vaccine Does Not Cause Autism, Says IOM. HealthLeaders Media.

items.description: Ecological analysis of Danish registers (1971–2000) showed autism incidence continued to rise after the removal of thimerosal from vaccines in 1992, with no correlation between thimerosal exposure levels (0–400 µg Hg) and autism risk (p=0.40).
items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., & Plesner, A.-M. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: Negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3 Pt 1), 604–606. doi:10.1542/peds.112.3.Part1.604

items.description: In a US retrospective cohort of 95,727 children with older siblings, MMR vaccination was not associated with increased ASD risk at age 2 (RR 0.76; 95% CI 0.49–1.18) or age 5 (RR 0.56; 95% CI 0.31–1.01) among high-risk children, indicating no subgroup vulnerability.
items.citation_apa: Jain, A., Marshall, J., Buikema, A., Bancroft, T., Kelly, J. P., & Newschaffer, C. J. (2015). Autism occurrence by MMR vaccine status among US children with older siblings with and without autism. JAMA, 313(15), 1534–1540. doi:10.1001/jama.2015.3077

items.description: Case-control study of 256 ASD and 752 control children found no association between cumulative or maximum daily antigen exposure from vaccines in the first two years and ASD risk, despite antigen loads decreasing from thousands to 315 over decades.
items.citation_apa: DeStefano, F., Price, C. S., & Weintraub, E. (2013). Risk of autism is not increased by 'too many vaccines too soon,' study shows. The Journal of Pediatrics, 163(1), 79–85. doi:10.1016/j.jpeds.2013.01.029

items.description: In a Danish cohort of 537,303 children, MMR-vaccinated children (n=440,655) had an adjusted relative risk (RR) of autism of 0.92 (95% CI, 0.68–1.24) and ASD of 0.83 (95% CI, 0.65–1.07), indicating no increased risk of autism following MMR vaccination.
items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Hviid, A., Vestergaard, M., Schendel, D., Wohlfahrt, J., Thorsen, P., Olsen, J., & Melbye, M. (2002). A population-based study of measles, mumps, and rubella vaccination and autism. New England Journal of Medicine, 347(19), 1477-1482. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa021134

items.description: After discontinuation of thimerosal-containing vaccines in Denmark in 1992, the incidence of autism continued to rise from 1991 to 2000 among children aged 2–10 years, with no decline in autism rates following thimerosal removal.
items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., Plesner, A. M., Andersen, P. H., & Mortensen, P. B. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: Negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3 Pt 1), 604-606. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.112.3.604

items.description: An updated Cochrane review of MMR, MMRV, and MMR+V vaccines found no evidence of increased autism risk and confirmed vaccine effectiveness, with moderate-to-high certainty across studies up to May 2019.
items.citation_apa: Di Pietrantonj, C., Rivetti, A., Marchione, P., Debalini, M. G., & Demicheli, V. (2019). Vaccines for measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 2019(4), CD004407. https://doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub2

items.description: In a case-control study of 256 ASD cases and 752 controls, increasing cumulative exposure to vaccine antigens up to age 2 years showed no association with ASD risk (aOR per 25-unit antigen increase ranged from 0.999 to 1.001).
items.citation_apa: DeStefano, F., Price, C. S., & Weintraub, E. S. (2013). Increasing exposure to antibody-stimulating proteins and polysaccharides in vaccines is not associated with risk of autism. Journal of Pediatrics, 163(2), 561-567. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpeds.2013.02.001

items.description: CDC states that extensive studies have found no link between receiving vaccines and developing ASD, and that no vaccine ingredients have been associated with increased autism risk.
items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2024, December 30). Autism and vaccines. CDC. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/about/autism.html

items.description: The Institute of Medicine’s 2011 report reviewed over 1,000 studies of eight vaccines and concluded there is no causal relationship between vaccination and autism, stating the evidence favors rejection of any causal link.
items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2011). Adverse Effects of Vaccines: Evidence and Causality. Washington, DC: National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/13164

items.description: The Editors of The Lancet formally retracted the 1998 Wakefield et al. paper in February 2010 after the UK General Medical Council found data falsification and unethical procedures, invalidating the initial suggestion of an MMR-autism link.
items.citation_apa: The Editors of The Lancet. (2010). Retraction—Ileal-lymphoid-nodular hyperplasia, non‐specific colitis, and pervasive developmental disorder in children. The Lancet. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(10)60175-7

items.description: The WHO Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety’s December 2025 review of 31 primary studies (2010–2025) and meta-analyses reaffirmed that vaccines, including those with thiomersal or aluminum adjuvants, do not cause ASD.
items.citation_apa: World Health Organization. (2025, December 11). WHO expert group’s new analysis reaffirms there is no link between vaccines and autism. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.who.int/news/item/11-12-2025-who-expert-group-s-new-analysis-reaffirms-there-is-no-link-between-vaccines-and-autism

items.description: A systematic review of 67 studies on routine pediatric vaccines in the United States found high-strength evidence that the MMR vaccine is not associated with autism, and moderate evidence of rare adverse events (e.g., intussusception with rotavirus vaccine), underscoring the overall safety of the immunization schedule.
items.citation_apa: Maglione, M. A., Das, L., Raaen, L., Smith, A., Chari, R., Newberry, S., Shanman, R., Perry, T., Goetz, M. B., & Gidengil, C. (2014). Safety of vaccines used for routine immunization of US children: A systematic review. Pediatrics, 134(2), 325–337. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.2014-1079

items.description: An analysis of unethical research practices and methodological flaws in studies promoting a vaccine–autism link, documenting fraudulent science associated with Andrew Wakefield and subsequent proponents, and highlighting the public health risks of such misinformation.
items.citation_apa: Flaherty, D. K. (2011). The vaccine–autism connection: A public health crisis caused by unethical medical practices and fraudulent science. Annals of Pharmacotherapy, 45(10), 1302–1304. https://doi.org/10.1345/aph.1P470

items.description: Geier & Geier (2003) analyzed the VAERS database and Department of Education data, finding dose-response curves indicating that increased cumulative mercury exposure from thimerosal-containing childhood vaccines correlated with higher rates of autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders.
items.citation_apa: Geier, D. A., & Geier, M. R. (2003). An assessment of the impact of thimerosal on childhood neurodevelopmental disorders. Pediatric Rehabilitation, 6(2), 97–102. https://doi.org/10.1080/1363849031000139315

items.description: Geier & Geier (2003) reported in Experimental Biology and Medicine that analysis of VAERS data showed a relative risk of 6.0 for autism and 6.1 for mental retardation following thimerosal-containing DTaP vaccines compared to thimerosal-free formulations.
items.citation_apa: Geier, M. R., & Geier, D. A. (2003). Neurodevelopmental disorders after thimerosal-containing vaccines: a brief communication. Experimental Biology and Medicine, 228(6), 660–664. https://doi.org/10.1177/153537020322800603

items.description: Madsen et al. (2003) analyzed Danish population-based data and observed that autism prevalence continued to rise following the removal of thimerosal from childhood vaccines in 1992, providing negative ecological evidence for a thimerosal-autism link.
items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., & Plesner, A. M. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3), 604–606. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.112.3.604

items.description: The Institute of Medicine Immunization Safety Review Committee (2004) concluded that the body of epidemiological evidence favors rejection of a causal relationship between both the MMR vaccine and thimerosal-containing vaccines and autism.
items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2004). Immunization Safety Review: Vaccines and Autism. National Academies Press. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK25344/

items.description: A nationwide Danish cohort study of 657,461 children born between 1999 and 2010 found that receipt of the MMR vaccine was not associated with an increased risk for autism (hazard ratio for vaccinated vs. unvaccinated children not significantly different from 1).
items.citation_apa: Hviid, A., Hansen, J. V., Frisch, M., & Melbye, M. (2019). Measles, mumps, rubella vaccination and autism: A nationwide cohort study. Annals of Internal Medicine, 170(8), 513–520. doi:10.7326/M18-2101

items.description: Ecological analysis of Danish children aged 2–10 diagnosed with autism from 1971 to 2000 showed no decline in autism incidence following removal of thimerosal from vaccines in 1992; autism rates continued to rise, refuting any correlation with thimerosal exposure.
items.citation_apa: Madsen, K. M., Lauritsen, M. B., Pedersen, C. B., Thorsen, P., Plesner, A. M., Andersen, P. H., & Mortensen, P. B. (2003). Thimerosal and the occurrence of autism: Negative ecological evidence from Danish population-based data. Pediatrics, 112(3 Pt 1), 604–606. doi:10.1542/peds.112.3.604

items.description: A Cochrane systematic review of MMR, MMRV, and MMR+V vaccines (up to May 2019) in over 13 million children found no evidence of increased autism risk among vaccinated vs. unvaccinated groups, while affirming vaccine effectiveness.
items.citation_apa: Di Pietrantonj, C., Rivetti, A., Marchione, P., Debalini, M. G., & Demicheli, V. (2012). Vaccines for measles, mumps, rubella and varicella in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 2, CD004407. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3

items.description: Case-control study of 256 ASD cases and 752 matched controls in three U.S. managed care organizations found no association between prenatal or infant thimerosal (ethylmercury) exposure and risk of ASD, autistic disorder, or ASD with regression.
items.citation_apa: Price, C. S., Thompson, W. W., Goodson, B., Weintraub, E. S., Croen, L. A., Hinrichsen, V. L., Marcy, M., Robertson, A., Eriksen, E., Lewis, E., Bernal, P., Shay, D., Davis, R. L., & DeStefano, F. (2010). Prenatal and infant exposure to thimerosal from vaccines and immunoglobulins and risk of autism. Pediatrics, 126(4), 656–664. doi:10.1542/peds.2010-0309

items.description: In a reanalysis of CDC data involving African American male children, vaccination with the first MMR dose before 24 months of age was associated with a 1.73-fold increased risk of autism diagnosis, and vaccination before 36 months was associated with a 3.36-fold increased risk, compared to later vaccination timing.
items.citation_apa: Hooker, B. S. (2014). Measles-mumps-rubella vaccination timing and autism among young African American boys: A reanalysis of CDC data. Translational Neurodegeneration, 3, 16. https://doi.org/10.1186/2047-9158-3-16

items.description: A cross-national preprint analysis of 12 high-income countries found a positive association between early-life vaccine scheduling intensity (number of doses administered to infants under one year) and standardized autism incidence rates, with higher-dose countries averaging 20 doses in the first year showing elevated autism prevalence compared to countries with fewer doses.
items.citation_apa: Coccia, M. (2025). Infant vaccine scheduling intensity and autism incidence: A preliminary cross-national analysis to guide public health policy [Preprint]. Preprints.org. https://www.preprints.org/manuscript/202511.0675

items.description: Brookings Institution experts argue that there is no scientific evidence supporting alternative ‘‘spaced-out’’ vaccine schedules for safety, noting that major reviews, including by the IOM, found no concerns with the current timing and that spacing delays increase risks for preventable diseases.
items.citation_apa: Brookings Institution. (2026). Vaccines and nervous parents: Why spacing out the vaccine schedule is not the answer. Brookings. https://www.brookings.edu/articles/vaccines-and-nervous-parents-why-spacing-out-the-vaccine-schedule-is-not-the-answer/

items.description: The Institute of Medicine’s 2013 comprehensive review of the U.S. childhood immunization schedule found no evidence that the timing, number, or order of vaccines is linked to autism or other developmental disorders, though it called for research on outcomes in children with delayed schedules.
items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2013). The Childhood Immunization Schedule and Safety: Stakeholder Concerns, Scientific Evidence, and Future Studies. National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/13563

items.description: In October 2025, the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices announced a multi-year review of the U.S. childhood vaccine schedule specifically to study timing and sequence of vaccinations, including alternative schedules used abroad and potential subgroup vulnerabilities.
items.citation_apa: Politico. (2025, October 9). CDC panel announces plans to assess childhood vaccine schedule. Politico. https://www.politico.com/news/2025/10/09/cdc-panel-to-assess-childhood-vaccine-schedule-00600304

items.description: A Medical Daily report summarizing a review of nearly 1,000 children concluded there is no evidence linking the timing or scheduling of childhood vaccines to the development of autism spectrum disorder.
items.citation_apa: Medical Daily. (2025). Study confirms no link between childhood vaccine schedule and autism. Medical Daily. https://www.medicaldaily.com/study-confirms-no-link-between-childhood-vaccine-schedule-and-autism-244822

clusters.description: Large cohort/case-control studies and meta-analyses examining MMR, thimerosal/ethylmercury, antigen load, prenatal influenza vaccination, and temporal/timing variables; overwhelmingly report no association with ASD.

H0.justification: Catch-all/OTHER does not specifically predict that repeated large studies will be null or positive; treat as independent of this evidence cluster → set to base rate exactly (LR=1).

H1.justification: If vaccines directly cause autism at a detectable population level, repeated large studies/meta-analyses would more often find an association; thus observing repeated nulls is much less likely than base rate.

H2.justification: If no causal link exists, repeated large studies should mostly report null associations; thus this null-heavy cluster is much more likely than base rate.

H3.justification: If only a rare vulnerable subgroup exists, most population-wide studies still tend to be null; so the cluster is somewhat more likely than base rate, though not as strongly as under H2.

H4.justification: An indirect/rare immune-interaction pathway would generally yield weak/rare effects, so many null epidemiologic findings remain somewhat expected; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule/timing effects exist only in limited circumstances, many broad studies would still be null; slightly above base rate (but less than H2), acknowledging some items in this cluster directly test timing/antigen-load.

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive about whether mainstream epidemiology yields null vs positive findings; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If one suspects residual confounding/healthy-user bias and publication/selection effects, null epidemiology is less surprising even if H1 were true; still somewhat below base rate because many independent datasets would not all wash out a real effect.

H2.justification: Null findings remain more expected under no-causation, but methodological skepticism reduces how strongly this cluster is predicted vs base rate.

H3.justification: Rare subgroup effects still allow many null results; modestly above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare effects are compatible with many nulls; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule effects could be hard to detect in standard observational designs; modestly above base rate but close to it under methodological skepticism.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict the direction of epidemiologic findings; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under a strongly vaccine-skeptical stance (systematic bias/suppression assumed), many null studies are expected even if a true effect exists; thus slightly above base rate rather than below.

H2.justification: Even under skepticism, null findings are still somewhat expected if there is no causal link; only slightly above base rate because the paradigm treats these results as less diagnostic.

H3.justification: Rare subgroup effects plus assumed detection limitations make null-heavy literature plausible; modestly above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare pathways can evade detection; modestly above base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule effects are real but obscured, null epidemiology is not very surprising; slightly above base rate.

clusters.description: Consensus statements and major reviews (IOM/NASEM, CDC, AAP, WHO, Brookings expert commentary, and similar) concluding no link between vaccines (including MMR, thimerosal/aluminum) and autism, and/or no schedule-timing link.

H0.justification: OTHER does not specifically predict whether institutions converge on 'no link' vs 'link'; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If vaccines truly cause autism broadly, strong cross-institutional consensus repeatedly rejecting a link is less likely than base rate (would expect more equivocation or positive findings).

H2.justification: If no causal link exists, major institutions reviewing large bodies of evidence are very likely to converge on 'no link'; far above base rate.

H3.justification: A rare subgroup effect could still yield broad institutional 'no population-level link' conclusions, but strong categorical messaging ('no link') is somewhat less expected than under H2; slightly below base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare immune-interaction effects would plausibly lead to more hedged institutional language; thus repeated strong 'no link' consensus is somewhat less likely than base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule timing/sequence truly mattered, large reviews specifically of schedules would be less likely to conclude 'no evidence'; thus below base rate.

H0.justification: Under skepticism about institutional incentives, consensus statements become less tied to underlying causal truth; OTHER still makes no specific prediction → set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If institutions are biased/motivated, 'no link' consensus could still occur even if H1 were true; thus only slightly below base rate.

H2.justification: Even with institutional skepticism, a true no-link world still modestly increases the chance institutions say 'no link'; slightly above base rate (reduced diagnosticity).

H3.justification: If institutions are not strongly truth-tracking, rare-subgroup hypotheses do not strongly change expected consensus outputs; approximately at base rate (treated as near-non-diagnostic here).

H4.justification: Same rationale as H3 under this paradigm: institutional conclusions expected to be relatively insensitive to nuanced indirect pathways → set near base rate.

H5.justification: If the schedule question is politically charged, institutions might still state reassurance regardless; treat as near base rate (low diagnosticity).

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive regarding institutional messaging; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under a strong vaccine-skeptic paradigm (institutional capture/suppression assumed), institutional 'no link' statements are expected even if vaccines cause autism; thus above base rate.

H2.justification: If there is truly no link, institutions may also say 'no link'; but under this paradigm such statements are not strongly truth-indicative, so only slightly below/near base rate (set slightly below to reflect expectation of institutional reassurance regardless).

H3.justification: If only a subgroup is affected, this paradigm still expects broad institutional denial; above base rate.

H4.justification: Same as H3 under K2: denial/consensus messaging expected even with nuanced indirect harm; above base rate.

H5.justification: If schedule effects exist, K2 expects institutions to continue reassuring the public; above base rate.

clusters.cluster_name: Wakefield episode: initial signal, then retraction/fraud analysis
clusters.description: The original small 1998 case series suggesting a temporal association, followed by formal retractions and analyses documenting methodological flaws/fraud and unethical practices.

H0.justification: OTHER does not specifically predict 'a flawed early study appears and is later retracted'; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If vaccines truly cause autism, one expects better-quality replicable signals rather than a landmark claim collapsing into fraud/retraction; thus this cluster is less likely than base rate.

H2.justification: If no causal link exists, early spurious associations plus subsequent correction/retraction is relatively likely; above base rate.

H3.justification: A rare-subgroup truth could still generate small early signals, but full fraud/retraction is less expected than under H2; modestly above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect/rare pathway could allow early suggestive reports, but wholesale invalidation remains more consistent with 'no link'; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule/timing effects could produce apparent temporal patterns, but this particular episode being fraudulent/retracted is not strongly predicted; slightly above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict this historical sequence; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If one allows for social/political contestation, retractions can occur even when some underlying risk exists; still below base rate because fraud findings weaken the expectation under H1.

H2.justification: Spurious early claims corrected later are expected under H2, but K1 reduces trust in the 'retraction implies false' inference; moderately above base rate.

H3.justification: Rare subgroup effects plus noisy early research could still end in retraction; slightly above base rate.

H4.justification: Similar to H3 under K1; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Timing-only theories are not strongly illuminated by this episode; near base rate but slightly above.

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive about this episode; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under a suppression/censorship paradigm, a prominent pro-link paper later retracted is expected if H1 is true; above base rate.

H2.justification: If no link exists, K2 considers retraction less diagnostic (could be politicized); thus only slightly below base rate.

H3.justification: If a subgroup effect exists, K2 still expects pushback/retraction dynamics; above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect pathways plus perceived suppression makes this episode somewhat expected; above base rate.

H5.justification: Timing/schedule theories can align with temporal narratives that later face institutional rejection; above base rate.

clusters.description: Animal/translational evidence that maternal immune activation can produce autism-like phenotypes, suggesting immune-mediated pathways could influence neurodevelopment (not vaccine-specific per se).

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict whether immune-activation animal models exist; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Direct vaccine-causation hypotheses often invoke immune activation/neuroinflammation mechanisms, so seeing such mechanistic models is somewhat more likely than base rate.

H2.justification: No-link between vaccines and autism is compatible with immune activation affecting neurodevelopment via infections/other exposures; not a specific vaccine prediction → set to base rate.

H3.justification: Subgroup vulnerability hypotheses predict that immune-related susceptibilities could matter; thus mechanistic immune-activation models are somewhat more likely than base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect pathway via immune activation explicitly predicts mechanistic support for immune-mediated neurodevelopmental disruption; well above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule-overload is not specifically about maternal immune activation in pregnancy; this evidence is largely orthogonal → set to base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER makes no specific prediction; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Mechanistic plausibility evidence is treated as more suggestive under K1; somewhat above base rate.

H2.justification: Still compatible and not specifically predicted by H2; set to base rate.

H3.justification: Immune-vulnerability framing fits subgroup susceptibility; above base rate.

H4.justification: Immune-activation mechanism is central to H4; above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule/timing hypotheses weakly connect via immune load ideas; slightly above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER is non-predictive; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under K2, immune activation animal models are taken as strong support for vaccine causation narratives; above base rate.

H2.justification: K2 treats immune-activation evidence as conflicting with 'no vaccine contribution'; thus below base rate.

H3.justification: K2 expects immune susceptibility to matter for a subgroup; above base rate.

H4.justification: Immune-activation pathway is strongly aligned; well above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule-overload claims often invoke immune mechanisms; somewhat above base rate.

clusters.cluster_name: Contrarian/contested evidence & ongoing reviews (VAERS/ecological signals, preprints, subgroup/timing claims, policy noise)
clusters.description: Weaker/contested pro-link claims (VAERS-based analyses, subgroup/timing reanalyses), critiques alleging bias in null studies, cross-national schedule correlations, and signals of renewed review/uncertainty; includes some mixed media summaries around schedule.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict the appearance of a mixed set of contrarian studies/claims and review announcements; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If vaccines cause autism, one expects at least some positive signals and persistent controversy; thus this cluster is more likely than base rate (even if individual items are low-quality).

H2.justification: If there is truly no causal link, some noise/false positives occur, but a concentration of pro-link claims plus policy 'reconsideration' is less likely than base rate.

H3.justification: Rare-subgroup effects predict occasional subgroup/timing signals and ongoing debate; above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect immune interactions could yield sporadic and hard-to-replicate signals; slightly above base rate.

H5.justification: Timing/schedule hypotheses predict schedule-intensity correlations and renewed schedule review; above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER remains non-predictive; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: If true harm exists and mainstream methods miss it, K1 expects persistent dissent, bias critiques, and positive signals in alternative analyses; above base rate.

H2.justification: Even with no link, motivated reasoning and p-hacking can yield contrarian signals; still below base rate but less strongly than K0.

H3.justification: Subgroup vulnerability fits occasional subgroup findings and ongoing re-analysis; above base rate.

H4.justification: Indirect pathways can be subtle and contested; modestly above base rate.

H5.justification: Schedule/timing concerns predict continued debate, ecological correlations, and institutional reviews; above base rate.

H0.justification: OTHER does not predict these specific contested signals; set to base rate exactly.

H1.justification: Under K2, contrarian signals, VAERS-based associations, subgroup timing effects, and policy reconsiderations are expected manifestations of a real causal relationship; well above base rate.

H2.justification: If no link exists, K2 views this cluster as comparatively unlikely; below base rate.

H3.justification: K2 expects subgroup signals and disputes if only some children are vulnerable; above base rate.

H4.justification: K2 expects immune-mediated controversies and sporadic signals; above base rate.

H5.justification: K2 expects schedule-intensity associations and renewed schedule scrutiny if timing matters; well above base rate.
